awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Compact Torus-Shaped Organic Ranking Cycle for Distributed Solar Thermal Power Generation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project addresses the current need to develop a small scale organic rankine cycle (ORC). While ORCs have been used extensively in industry for waste heat recovery for larger systems (10kW and above), there has been little advancement in the private sector for smaller ORCs used for distributed solar power, biomass or diesel waste heat recovery  for smaller portable/compact  applications. While smaller systems are known to work through various demonstrations at research institutions, it has yet been proven whether they can be manufactured and sold at a competitive cost to replace current distributed power systems for remote applications. The proposed design packages all components in a way to optimize system efficiency, reduce complexity and increase manufacturability. The research effort will consist of assessing the feasibility of designing a working compact ORC that can be competitive in the areas of life cycle cost, reliability, efficiency and performance. This will be accomplished through design, fabrication and testing of a portion of the system. This project will seek to develop a smaller and novel organic ranking cycle system for commercial use that is practical and highly competitive.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project can be narrowed down to two main markets. The first includes use for distributed solar power generation. ORCs offer a cheaper alternative to solar photovoltaic (PV) for distributed solar power generation in that thermal energy can be easily stored on site without the use of large expensive batteries as in solar PV. With reduction in cost in both generation and storage, ORC solar power generation can potentially be available to markets where the costly PV is not an option. This includes markets in underdeveloped countries where solar energy is plentiful, yet the infrastructure to support grid energy storage doesn?t exist; as well as remote markets where an electrical grid doesn?t exist and energy storage is required. An additional market includes distributed biomass power generation for small independent farms, currently expensive anaerobic digesters or large steam driven biomass plants are used for biomass energy production from farm waste. The low power density of farm waste makes it impractical to transport long distances to these facilities. With the use of a affordable compact ORC, energy from biomass can be generated on-site at an affordable cost.

por.por_cntn:
Air Squared, Inc. (ASI) recently completed a Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase I award from the National Science Foundation (NSF) for a novel Compact Torus-Shaped Organic Rankine Cycle design (Pat. Pend.). An Organic Rankine Cycle (ORC) uses organic fluids to extract power from low temperature energy sources. The waste-heat to power device could be used to convert low-grade heat sources like biomass or renewable thermal energy into usable electric power.

 Commercially available ORC systems are constructed in an elementary manner, with each component existing independently, making installation not only costly, but impractical for most locations. The compact torus-shaped ORC integrates all system components into a cylinder - equivalent in size to residential HVAC outdoor units. The design makes the ORC a viable option in the residential power generation market.    

 The primary objective of the Phase I SBIR was to qualify the positioning of the heat exchangers (evaporator and condenser) in the uniquely shaped 1.5 kW ORC. The goal was to achieve 80% effectiveness in both components. Phase I of the SBIR was successfully completed in six months, with all development and testing conducted at Air Squared’s facility in Broomfield, CO.

 In connection to the Societal Challenges area of Energy Efficiency and Alternative and Renewable Energy, the SBIR examined the feasibility of several uses for the device, including waste-heat from biomass and integration with solar thermal technology. With renewed interest in low-grade heat recovery, the Compact ORC could have a far-reaching impact, making self-sustaining energy possible for rural and residential communities.

The residential solar thermal panels can provide hot water to power the Compact ORC. The higher the temperature of water the more power the Compact ORC is able to generate. This has rekindled interest from solar thermal industry for development of the solar panels. With the Compact ORC able to generate power from heat at residential level, it brings competition into a market dominated by solar photovoltaic.

 ASI has completed custom scroll developments for several ORC projects over a wide range of conditions and working fluids. The Compact Torus-Shaped ORC leverages Air Squared's significant scroll design experience. ASI will develop the scroll pump and expander running of the same shaft in the next phase of the project.
